other_tests.findings: The right vertebral artery was prominent with high-velocity, low-resistance flow on the Doppler study, whereas the left vertebral artery showed flow reversal with a high-resistance waveform.

Revealed a right-sided aorta giving three branches: the left common carotid, the right common carotid, and the right subclavian. The left subclavian artery was not visualized in the mediastinum, communicating with a small-caliber left vertebral artery. A right-sided tracheal bronchus was noted, and the right main bronchus was compressed between the aorta and the right pulmonary artery.

At first, it revealed the absence of flow-related enhancement in the left vertebral artery, likely due to flow reversal. Upon repeating the test with saturation bands removed, flow enhancement was noted in the left vertebral artery joining the left subclavian artery, with no flow enhancement in the subclavian artery proximal to the joining.
